title-group.article-title: Special 2013 Issue of Teaching Sociology on Writing

body.p: Writing is an essential element of sociological pedagogy. Many of our classes rely on written work as the means for students to demonstrate their acquisition of a sociological perspective. This special issue of Teaching Sociology will address critical issues and the unique concerns that we face related to the use of written work in our discipline. What are the key features of “good sociological writing” and how do we teach them? What does the pedagogy of writing look like in our discipline? Why do we use these strategies to teach writing? What are the critical challenges in teaching writing and how do we address them in our assignments and syllabi? For many, if not most of us, writing is one important strategy that we use both to deepen and broaden student thinking and then to assess these changes. The goal of this issue is to showcase the wide range of approaches, forms and purposes that sociologists ascribe to the written work we assign in our classes.

We hope this issue will expose and dissect the ways in which we transmit our logic surrounding writing pedagogy in our discipline to the students in our classrooms, our colleagues and institutional leaders. We encourage papers that explore the meaning and application of writing across a wide range of themes and provide evidence of improvement in student writing and critical thinking skills.
Papers that examine writing as a theoretical concept might:

list-item.p: Explore the theoretical linkages between writing and thinking
Discuss the ways in which we define “written work” in sociology and its application to the process of knowledge making
Articulate the role and definition of writing in relation to student learning

body.p: Papers that consider writing as a pedagogical strategy within specific classes might:

list-item.p: Describe the implementation of a written assignment (e.g., journals or research papers) that are grounded in the scholarship of teaching and learning
Present writing exercises that can be used to deepen the understanding of core disciplinary concepts
Demonstrate classroom strategies that can be used to enhance the development of writing skills

body.p: Papers that analyze written work as a departmental and institutional goal might:

list-item.p: Define the relationship between University policies on writing and departmental goals for written work
Demonstrate the ways in which institutional policies on writing can impinge upon what is (and is not) done with writing in the major
Describe successful departmental approaches for organizing students’ writing experience within the major or the creation linkages between writing in the discipline and writing done in core classes
Analyze the role of writing as a means to assess outcomes in disciplinary learning

body.p: The submitted papers will undergo the usual peer review process and will need to meet Teaching Sociology’s submission guidelines, which can be found here: (http://www.sagepub.com/journalsProdDesc.nav?ct_p=manuscriptSubmission&prodId=Journal201974). We strongly encourage authors to incorporate the broader literature on the scholarship of teaching and learning about writing as well sociological literature in their work. Submissions should be uploaded to the ScholarOne Teaching Sociology portal (http://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/ts) by June 1, 2012. During the submission process, authors should clearly write the editor that this manuscript is submitted for the special edition.

If you have questions about the special edition, feel free to ask Special Guest Editor, Suzanne Hudd (suzanne.hudd@quinnipiac.edu) or Kathleen S. Lowney, editor of Teaching Sociology (teachingsociology@valdosta.edu).
